prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus Binaries
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe dust continuum and molecular lines toward binary protostars in the Perseus molecular cloud.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our observations will be conducted in the most extended configuration offered in order to resolve the individual proto-binary sources. The declination of Perseus is about 31 degrees (max. elevation 36 degrees), casuing the beam to be elongated in the north-south direction yielding 0.35" X 0.2" resolution; the 0.15" elongation will not affect our ability to resolve these close binary sources. The largest angular scale in the observations will be 4.16", encompassing the entire area shown in Figure 1 subpanels. This is more than enough spatial sensitivity to detect circumbinary structure on the scale of ~950 AU around these sources. The surrounding envelopes will be resolved-out, but this will not affect our science goal of examining the small scale structure directly associated with the protobinary sources. The C18O and 13CO emission that traces disk rotation will be spatially unresolved in the line wings at velocities greater than +/- 0.5 km/s from line center.
We will observe the C18O and 13CO (J=2-1) lines the same base-band, allocating half the correlator resources to each line and observing with a 60 MHz bandwidth, 0.083 km/s velocity resolution. We will also observe the 12CO (J=2-1) line with 234 MHz bandwidth and 0.16 km/s channels. The higher velocity resolution is necessary for the C18O and 13CO observations because we are aiming to map the rotation curve of the disk. The 12CO line is expected to trace the outflow emission and may be spread over a larger velocity range necessitating lower velocity resolution and broader overall bandwidth. We are allocating two basebands to observe the 1.3 mm continuum emission with a total of 4GHz of bandwidth in order to examine the compact dust emission surrounding the protostars.
Our overall time estimate is driven by the sensitivity requirement of the C18O (J=2-1) observations, which is 15 mJy/beam in a 0.084 km/s velocity channel. This sensitivity will enable us to detect the high-velocity line wings of C18O and 13CO associated with disk rotation out to at least +/- 2 km/s from line center (see Figure 3). The strength of C18O emission will vary between sources, thus we are using ALMA Cycle 0 observations of the sources L1527 and VLA1623 and CARMA observations of L1165 to guide our sensitivity limts. These sources span the luminosity range that we will examine ~ 1 Lsun for VLA 1620 to 15 Lsun for L1165. We have scaled the expected flux densities to the distance of Perseus (230 pc) and the emission at +/- 2.0 km/s from line center in a given velocity channel is 74 mJy/beam for L1527, 59 mJy/beam for VLA 1623, and 250 mJy/beam for L1165. Thus, we can expect signal-to-noise ratios to range from ~17 to ~4 at +/- 2 km/s from line center; at lower velocities the emission will be stronger, so this lower limit of our expected signal-to-noise in the channel maps. A signal-to-noise ratio >= 4 is necessary to accurately centroid position of line emission at the high-velocities because the relative positional accuracy is ~ beam/signal-to-noise.
The integration time necessary for the line observations will yield a continuum sensitivity of 0.06 mJy with the 4 GHz of bandwidth. This sensitivity is more than enough to detect the individual sources, in addition to an compact circumbinary disk structures. For comparison, the 1.3 mm observations shown in Figure 2 had a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy and detected the circumbinary disk with high confidence. The requested ALMA observations will exceed this sensitivity by a factor of 10, enabling the detection of any compact circumbinary structures with high significance.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Over 50% of sun-like stars are found in binary/multiple systems. Their formation is thought to occur during the early stages of the star formation process, but the formation mechanism remains unclear. The most likely possibilities are either disk fragmentation or turbulent fragmentation with dynamical evolution. To understand protostellar multiplicity, we have conducted a VLA 8 mm survey of all protostars (N~80) in the Perseus molecular cloud (d=230 pc) at a resolution of 0.3" (70 AU). With this unprecedented survey, we identified 17 close proto-binary systems with separations less than 500 AU, and of these, 14 are new discoveries. While these detections are significant, the VLA data do not convey their formation mechanism. Therefore, we propose to use ALMA to observe dust continuum and molecular line emission (C18O, 13CO) toward these 17 sources to determine if these sources have circumbinary disks in the apparent dust continuum and we will use the molecular line maps to determine if the disks are rotationally-supported. This sample is large enough to reveal general trends as to whether or not binaries typically form via disk fragmentation or turbulent fragmentation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
